thread.section_title: Sports - The Daily Reporter - Coldwater, MI
thread.title: Tekonsha dominates St. Joseph 70-28

author: Troy Tennyson Twitter: @ttennysonTDR
title: Tekonsha dominates St. Joseph 70-28
text: By Troy Tennyson Posted Oct. 17, 2015 at 12:20 PM Updated Oct 17, 2015 at 12:20 PM By Troy Tennyson Posted Oct. 17, 2015 at 12:20 PM Coldwater, Mich. TEKONSHA — The Tekonsha Indians need to win the rest of their games in order to even have an outside shot of making the playoffs as a five win team. Tekonsha took that first step in a big way Friday night, as they defeated St. Joseph Michigan Lutheran 70-28. The game started out in favor of St. Joseph, as they scored on their first possession to take a quick 8-0 lead. Tekonsha answered right back with a big score of their own, as senior athlete Isaac Mead scrambled in to the end zone from 38-yards out to give the Indians their first points of the game. Mead would then run in the two-point conversion to tie the score at 8-8. St. Joseph came back to score again, taking a 16-8 lead before the Indians hit pay dirt again. Dwight Devenney ran the ball in from 56-yards out, and with an Andy Galliers two-point conversion catch from Jordan Morrison the score stood tied at 16-16. Mead added to the Indians score total with less than :20 seconds remaining in the first quarter on a 47-yard run. The two point conversion was no good making the score 22-16. St. Joseph scored again to tie the game at 22-22 before Devenney put Tekonsha up for good with a 39-yard touchdown run, making the score 28-22. Tekonsha then scored two unanswered touchdowns, one by Mead from seven yards out and one by Devenney to make the score 44-22. St. Joseph added a score just before the half to bring the score to 44-28 in favor of Tekonsha. It was all Indians after the half, as Mead scored three times in the second half on runs of 22-yards, 59-yards, and on a 65-yard punt return to put the game fully out of reach. Noah Mead would add a touchdown for the Indians at the 9:56 mark to make the score 70-28. Isaac Mead led the Indians explosive offensive attack with eight carries for 296 yards and five touchdowns, plus a 65-yard punt return touchdown. Dwight Devenney had eight carries for 153 yards and three touchdowns, while Noah Mead added seven carries for 52 yards. Jordan Morrison added seven carries for 49 yards and went 1 of 7 passing for 39 yards, with the one completion going to Isaac Mead. Gabe Rapelje and Isaac Mead led the Indians defensively with 17 total tackles each, while Anthony Komasara and Takoda McDonald each added 11 tackles. AJ Crisp had 11 tackles while Connor Jenksings added eight and Jake Hanks added seven in the winning effort. With the win the Indians improve to 4-4 on the season and will look to finish on a strong note next week when they travel to Litchfield. Union City suffers heartbreak at Homer Page 2 of 2 - HOMER — The Union City Chargers postseason chances took a big hit Friday night as they suffered a heartbreaking loss to the Homer Trojans 40-34. Union City got first half scores from Elijah Way who busted off a 60-yard touchdown run, followed closely by a Jalen Boes 76 yard kick return for a touchdown, putting the score at 22-12 in favor of Homer at the half. Union City added scores in the third quarter on a Boes 13-yard run, a Way 33-yard run, and a Seth Bruce 56-yard pass to Colin Kreger, however it just wasn't enough as the Chargers fell to the first place Trojans. Union City was led by Elijah Way who had five carries for 93 yards and two scores, while Thomas Anderson added five carries for 41 yards and Jalen Boes added eight carries for 41 yards and one touchdown. Seth Bruce added 13 carries for 48 yards while also going 8 of 17 passing for 98 yards and one touchdown. Colin Kreger led the Chargers in receiving, catching three balls for 63 yards and one score. Defensively, Union City was led by Way who had 10 tackles, followed by Bransom Turley with eight tackles, and Jalen Boes who had six tackles. Tristan Banks added four tackles and an interception in the loss. With the loss the Chargers fall to 4-4 on the season and will look to end on a high note next week in the Cascade Conference cross-over game. By Troy Tennyson   By Troy Tennyson
